rText: I bought this phone to replace a base and satellite I've had for years and just couldn't stand their fuzziness anymore.  I read a lot of reviews on the Walmart site and felt it was a good bet.  I love the red!  Makes it hard to lose and it looks spiffy too.  The sound is clear.  It has the caller ID and speaker phone I was looking for.  I was able to figure out how to program in my frequently called numbers without using the instructions.  The price couldn't be beat.  I bought two.  My only disappointment was that they were sold out of the base and remote sets in this brand.  These say that they are "expandable" so I'm hoping that  the base set becomes available so I can link them to  rooms without a phone jack.  Good Little Phone, Great Price!

Red
pTitle: VTech CS6919-16 DECT 6.0 Expandable Cordless Phone with Caller ID and Handset Speakerphone, Red
rText:
The phone was a reasonable price and has many of the features I needed for a quick replacement phone.  I was hoping the quality and volume of the sound coming from the phone wouldn't make me regret this choice.  I'm using this in a VOIP situation, so I realize the call quality can be heavily dependent on the call connection itself - a hit or miss with my VOIP service lately.  I found the volume of the sound for the handset was a little weak.  Even when using the speaker phone of the handset itself and not the base, the volume was still a little soft.  I never tried using the phone when mounted in the base to test speaker quality when in the base.

I tried to use the redial feature where you can select beyond only the most recent call made.  This phone doesn't have that even though I have other similar phones that do.  

The display was a little weak and hard to read unless looking directly at the display and not in direct or bright light, or not too dark either.  You have to  hit it just right.  Again, I'm comparing this to similar products that I normally would be using.  For that reason, I'm being critical of the phone's features, but it will do for now as a substitute.

Overall this wasn't a bad solution for my temporary need, in spite of a few short comings.  The phone could be better and I'm glad it wasn't a lot worse.
rTitle: Ok, but not the best solution

Then you are going to repeat the process for each additional phone.

pDescr:
Android Smartphone 

Unlimited talk, text & data usage First 6 GB at high-speed* 
*Req's $60 monthly plan. After first 6 GB, data speeds are slowed to max of 128 Kbps for rest of 30-day term. 4G LTE not avail. everywhere. 
AT&T LG Phoenix 2 K371 Prepaid GoPhone:
5.0" HD display
5 megapixel front camera delivers impressive selfies
Up to 16GB internal memory
microSD up to 32GB
Curve display and distinctive rear key
Android 6.0 (Marshmallow) OS
Talk Time: Up to 12 h and 48 minutes
Standby Time: Up to 15.9 days
pTitle: AT&T LG Phoenix 2 Prepaid GoPhone
rText: It is hard to imagine how LG could even make this phone for $70. I bought two at WalMart for my wife and me, our first smartphones, along with two 32GB micro-SD cards. We love the LG design with all the buttons on the back instead of the sides. It's a fully functioning Android Marshmallow, no compromises on the OS. Despite these being "Go" phones they can be put on an ATT or Consumer Cellular plan; we're on Consumer Cellular. It's now 6 months later and our phones just updated to Nougat (Android 7) automatically; there are some very expensive phones that won't be getting Nougat - this is just amazing. One of the few downsides of this phone was its not-so-great battery life with Marshmallow, but with Nougat I can see already that battery life will be very nice. 4G performance is good. It's not the fastest processor out there, but very usable. Caveats for picky people: screen quality can be different from phone to phone, so make sure you get a good one (look for evenness of the white ATT screen when it boots). The camera shoots great quality video and reasonable quality still photos (strangely the video quality beats the still quality); in low light though it's hard to get good photos or videos, but hey it's a $70 phone. I can't say enough about how much we enjoy these! I don't envy my buddies with their $700 phones at all.

pTitle: AT&T LG Phoenix 2 Prepaid GoPhone
rText: Save your money and buy something different.   Don't even bother trying to take pictures with it because they will come out horrible and grainy at best no matter what lighting.   The phone freezes up at times and sometimes won't even "wake up" when I tap it.  Also when I receive a phone call, even though I'm frantically trying to answer the call, it won't answer it.  A total piece of junk.

pTitle: AT&T LG Phoenix 2 Prepaid GoPhone
rText:
I looove the LG Phones, you really can't go wrong.  My last phone (on AT&T contract) broke and AT&T wouldn't let me upgrade for another 10 months.  More ways to skin a chicken than one, so I purchased the AT&T GO PHONE, downloaded everything from my old phone into new one and VIOLA!!  I've had Samsungs but was not impressed.  I'll continue owning Lg's.  And forget the contract and high priced phones, this one does everything I need a phone to do!!!!
Oh yes, and it was priced CHEAPER at the store. So unless you really need to have it shipped to your house, just go pick one up at the local Wal-mart!!!
Great phone!!!

pTitle: AT&T LG Phoenix 2 Prepaid GoPhone
rText:
The battery life is terrible. In just 3 hours the phone dropped from full charge to half and it was not in use. 
The keyboard layout is awful. I spend far more time backspacing than I do typing. 
Camera specs on the box gave me false hope. Pictures are grainy and difficult to make out, even in well lit areas. 
10 minutes into setting the phone up, I noticed a considerable amount of lag, which was the first red flag with this phone. 

I love the design and the ease of use, but that's about it. I'm sure this phone would be wonderful for someone who is just diving into the world of smartphones, but for an advanced user, there are far too many flaws. 

I need a reliable, well functioning phone,  and I'm not so sure I will get that with this phone. I will be returning it, sadly.

pTitle: AT&T LG Phoenix 2 Prepaid GoPhone
rText:
At $70, it's hard to beat. The camera is probably one of the worst I've ever seen on a phone, but the display, hand feel and general operation are superb at this price point. 

NFC / Android Pay works well. However, there is no ability to cast or connect to wireless displays. This means, no screen mirroring with Roku.

The battery is very small and will discharge quickly, so keep a charger handy. 

1.5GB of RAM and Marshmallow 6.0 work well together, as does LG's "double-tap" to wake and rear-mounted volume and power buttons.

Overall, you can tell this is a 2016 phone vs. a 2015 phone that's been reduced in price. I wouldn't hesitate recommending, especially if this is a 2nd (beater) phone.
rTitle: No better phone for the price

pTitle: AT&T LG Phoenix 2 Prepaid GoPhone
rText:
... Like some folks, I've gone through severals smartphones over the years. Personally, I like having the option of switching between two phones (a casual phone for personal use and a smaller "I don't mind if I lose or break it phone" for work and play). Just swap out the sim card between the two phones as needed.

... When shopping for my backup phone, the size and specs sold me:  5-inch screen (1,280x720-pixel resolution),16GB internal storage, 1.5GB RAM and the MicroSD card support (up to 32GB) but the 2125mAh battery had me concerned. I mean it doesn't matter how good the overall specs are and phone performs, if your charge runs out, you're screwed. As with other LG phones I've owned in the past, I really enjoy the Double Tap ON/OFF feature.

 ... Just feel like a little larger battery would have been much more effective for the size and hardware. By the way, I know I have available options: purchase spare battery or plug it into to a cigarette light or outlet but it's a slight inconvenience at times. According to the phone's battery usage, the screen sucks up around 48% and I have it set on 30% with a shut off time of 2 minutes.

... Have only had the phone for a week but I did play music on the MP3 player while cutting grass with headphones on for 3 hours, with a couple of 10 minute phone calls and 2 text messages and the battery dropped 40%. Most days, I get online for roughly 10 minutes (youtube videos, 10 text messages and 40-60 minutes of phone calls). I'm not a gamer. Hopefully the phone will make it through the day with light use such as me.

... As far as the camera goes. With mid to low lighting (with or without flash on) you'll most like be disappointed. I'm not a big selfie taker but when I did with this phone, the quality was bad. Good lighting definitely makes a huge difference, much better. Just would have expected a little better quality with 8-megapixel rear and 5-megapixel front-facing camera. 

... My other current phones are Alcatel Idol 3 and ZTE ZMAX 2. Both perform extremely well without having to back off on any battery sucking functions of the phone. The ZTE ZMAX 2 is an excellent budget phone. Even purchased it at Walmart. Don't know why they stopped carrying it? Just wish it was a little smaller size for my needs. Overall for a mid priced budget phone, the LG Phoenix is ok. Oh well, good luck!
